The History of Irish Immigrants in the United States

Creator: Detroit Publishing Co.

Title: Coal Mine

Date: Between 1915 and 1925

Format: Photograph

Institution: Detroit Publishing Company photograph collection (Library of Congress)

Link: https://www.loc.gov/resource/det.4a27859/?co=det

The first wave of Irish immigrants arrived in the United States between 1820 and 1930. According to a census, the report estimates that as many as 4.5 million Irish made the voyage. Motivated to come to America because of the Potato Blight, a fungus that annihilated the potato crops of millions of farmers. The Potato Blight led to a great famine, which resulted in millions of Irish families to face starvation. When the Irish arrived in America, life was not easy. Irish immigrants found themselves to work in positions at the bottom of the occupational ladder. Many Irish immigrants found work in dangerous jobs, jobs that most people would avoid signing up for. Many Irish men would work in coal mines and railroad companies. The Irish faced an incredible amount of discrimination in the workforce. Many businesses took advantage of Irish workers, exploiting their willingness to work dangerous jobs for low pay.
